description: From Middle English slight (“bad, of poor quality, unimportant, trivial, slender, slim, smooth, level”), from Old English sliht (“smooth, level”), from Proto-Germanic *slihtaz (“slippery, flat, level, plain”), related to English slick. Cognate with Scots slicht (“bad, of poor quality”), West Frisian sljocht (“smooth, level, plain, simple”), Dutch slecht (“bad”), Low German slecht (“bad”), German schlecht (“bad”) and schlicht (“plain, artless, natural”), Danish slet (“bad, evil, poor, nasty, wrong”), Swedish slät (“smooth”), Norwegian slett (“even”), Icelandic sléttur (“even, smooth, level”).

entries.meaning: gentle or weak, not aggressive or powerful

examples: Some firmly embrace doctrines upon slight grounds.

entries.meaning: (archaic or rare) not far away in space or time

examples: Synonyms: flat, glassy, slick; see also Thesaurus:smooth

entries.meaning: (especially said of the sea) still; with little or no movement on the surface
examples: The sea was slight and calm
Synonyms: daft, fatuous, soft in the head; see also Thesaurus:foolish
we frequently have slight Goods and sometimes old and unsaleable Articles
Synonyms: contemptuous, disdainful, scornful; see also Thesaurus:disdainful

entries.meaning: The act of ignoring or snubbing; a deliberate act of neglect or discourtesy.

verbs.description: slight (third-person singular simple present slights, present participle slighting, simple past and past participle slighted)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To treat as unimportant or not worthy of attention; to make light of.
examples: the wretch who slights the bounty of the skies

entries.meaning: (transitive) To give lesser weight or importance to.
examples: Incontiguously (accent on tig; the rest of the syllables slighted) means in an incontiguous manner.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To treat with disdain or neglect, usually out of prejudice, hatred, or jealousy; to ignore disrespectfully.
examples: Though true of heart, she was somewhat of a coquette in manner; and I was jealous as a Turk. She slighted me in a thousand ways, yet would never acknowledge herself to be in the wrong. She would drive me mad with anger, and then force me to beg her pardon.

entries.meaning: (transitive, military, of a fortification) To render no longer defensible by full or partial demolition.
(obsolete, transitive) To make even or level.
